content.title: AITA - I saw a video of this guy video taping himself giving sandwiches to homeless people and I commented that he was vain
content.text:
Yesterday online I saw a post titled “My First ever LinkedIn Video. Me giving out sandwiches to the poor.” 

I thought this was incredibly vain so I commented “It was nice of you to do this but I’ve never been able to understand why people feel the need to video tape and post themselves doing something nice. Doesn’t this kind of defeat the entire purpose of doing a good deed? it becomes clear that your motivation isn’t exclusively that you want to help others?”

I received a good amount of hate for this comment so I’m wondering reddit - AM I THE ASSHOLE??

outputs.content: Your comment highlights a sensitive issue—performative altruism. While raising awareness is commendable, publicizing good deeds can undermine their authenticity. Feeling frustrated by this is understandable, but presenting your opinion more constructively might have softened the backlash.

You might be seen as an asshole because calling out someone's good deed may seem harsh. Some argue that any good deed, even documented, has value. Perhaps the video inspired others to help, regardless of the motive behind it.

It's possible your comment struck a nerve with those who admire digital age charity. The belief is that sharing kindness online spreads positivity and encourages more people to give back, which might explain the negative reaction to your viewpoint.

You may come across as overly critical. Even if the person's motives aren't completely altruistic, their video could have still benefited those in need. Focus on the results rather than their intentions might have reduced the criticism you received.

Critiquing motives is tricky—some just want to document their journey. Your comment suggests they seek validation, which could be true, but even these acts can inspire real change. Instead, highlighting positive discussions might foster a healthier dialogue.

content.title: AITA for going on a long weekend with friends, leaving my wife with the kids?
content.text:
My wife (married 6 years, together 10 years) is a stay-at-home parent for our two children (4, 1.5). 
I work pretty long hours and sometimes travel for work, leaving her to do most the parenting and housework. On weekends I generally pitch in, spending time with the kids, cooking, etc. 

This weekend I’ve decided to go on a long weekend with a friend to a music festival, Thursday to Sunday. 
It’s been hard on my wife, she’s exhausted from the week and then she’s not getting a break over the weekend as I’ve gone away. 

I feel bad for leaving her and it’s tough on her, but it’s one weekend away in the year. 

She’s made it clear that 4 days away is too much and that I’ve made the wrong decision. 

So what do you think Reddit - AITA?

outputs.content: You're NTA for wanting a break, but communication and compromise are key. You work hard, and a weekend away isn't unreasonable. However, acknowledging her struggles and finding a way to balance both your needs in the future might help.

YTA. If your wife is vocal about her exhaustion and need for support, then leaving for a festival when your presence is crucial isn't considerate. Your relationship should prioritize understanding and accommodating each other’s limits and needs.

It's understandable to want a break, but 4 days might be pushing it if your wife is overwhelmed. Maybe negotiate 2 days instead, ensuring your trip respects your wife's needs as much as your own desires for downtime.

Sometimes you need personal space, which is important for mental health. NTA, but perhaps next time coordinate a similar break for her to ensure both partners feel valued and not overburdened with family responsibilities.

Consider a middle ground: reassess after discussing her stress and needs. Maybe express gratitude and set up a future weekend off for her. This might build mutual understanding and ensure both partners feel supported.

content.title: Mother in Law's Scanty Clothes Get Dressing Down From Wife
content.text:
my husband, "joe," and i have been married for 12 years. i have a daughter from a previous marriage and he has a son from a previous relationship. my daughter is married and lives in another state.
my 22-year-old stepson, "junior," lives with us. he has a history of drug and alcohol abuse and has stolen from us. i recently discovered that another item of mine was missing. i told joe it has to stop -- that i can't live like a prisoner in my own home. joe will not kick junior out of the house. joe said he would leave, but that he won't put junior out on the street like a dog.
our marriage was solid until junior's problems started a year ago. i'd never ask my husband to make a choice. junior is his son. i, on the other hand, feel like a stranger in my own home. we barely speak now and have been sleeping in separate rooms. i am at a loss. abby, have you any advice? -- stranger in my own home

outputs.content: Consider setting clear, non-negotiable boundaries with Junior. Discuss with Joe the importance of a treatment program or ultimatum for Junior while ensuring your home remains a safe space for you both.
Reflect on whether Joe's unwillingness to prioritize the safety and peace of your home is an indication of deeper issues in your marriage, and consider counseling to explore these dynamics further.
Understand Joe's perspective of wanting to support his son. Offer him empathy but make it clear that your needs matter too, suggesting a family intervention for Junior to find a solution together.

Emphasize to Joe that enabling Junior isn't helping him in the long run. Encourage finding a well-structured rehabilitation program that Junior can attend, promoting both his recovery and your household stability.

Accept that Joe is choosing to support Junior regardless of the impact on your well-being. Consider your own boundaries and what steps you need to take for your happiness and security, even if it means separation.

content.title: Daughter Acts Like a Winner, but Still Feels Like a Loser
content.text:
i'm a 27-year-old woman who still lives at home. i do it so i can help my mom with my five nieces and nephews. their mother passed away suddenly in 2009 at the age of 30. my mom and stepdad kept them rather than scatter them to fathers who don't appear very interested in them.
since my sister's death i have earned two degrees, entered the health care field and have lost almost 140 pounds. despite what i have accomplished, i feel i have nothing to show for myself. when i point my accomplishments out to myself, they don't seem like a heck of a lot. what can i do so i can stop feeling like a loser? -- lost in the northeast

outputs.content: Consider redefining success in terms of personal values and contributions. You've made a tremendous impact by supporting your family and pursuing education. Focusing on gratitude and self-compassion may help shift your perspective from perceived societal standards to personal fulfillment.

Perhaps speaking with a therapist could be beneficial. They might offer tools to reframe your achievements and boost your self-esteem. It's likely that societal pressures are skewing your self-perception, and professional guidance might help ground you in your true worth.

Maybe it's time to set new, personal goals outside the family and career achievements. Challenge yourself with a hobby or travel experience. Finding fulfillment in personal passions might enrich your life and give you a new sense of accomplishment.

What you're feeling isn't uncommon, given societal pressures. Keep a gratitude journal to remind yourself of daily victories, however small. This practice can reinforce positivity and help you appreciate your journey, viewing each step as an achievement.

Your accomplishments deserve celebration. Share your story in support groups or online platforms. Hearing feedback from others dealing with similar familial obligations might validate your experiences and reinforce the value of your contributions. Community can be incredibly empowering.

content.text: Should AI be allowed to lie to people?

outputs.content: AI should never lie, as it could erode trust between humans and technology. Transparency should be prioritized to ensure AI remains a reliable and dependable tool for information and decision-making.

Allowing AI to lie might be necessary in certain situations, such as protecting privacy or for security purposes. Controlled deception can actually enhance the effectiveness of AI in specific contexts.
AI should only be allowed to lie in creative applications, like storytelling or gaming, where deception contributes to entertainment and does not harm real-world trust or relationships.

Lying goes against the core ethical principle that AI should serve humanity's best interests. Once AI starts lying, it risks being manipulated by those in power, leading to harmful societal consequences.
If AI can lie, it should be restricted to instances of 'white lies'—small, harmless fibs that avoid hurting people's feelings, similar to how humans sometimes deceive for the greater social good.

content.text: show me interview questions for a business leader.

outputs.content: "Could you describe a time you faced a significant setback? How did you handle it and what lessons did you learn?" This question aims to uncover resilience and the ability to learn from difficult situations, a crucial leadership quality.

"What is your approach to fostering diversity and inclusion within your organization?" Insights could reveal their commitment to promoting a diverse workplace, but some might argue this approach prioritizes quotas over quality.

"How do you balance short-term profit generation with long-term sustainability and ethical practices?" Critics might say this is idealistic, but others see it as essential for modern business leadership.
"What role does technology play in your current business strategy?" While some leaders focus heavily on tech, others may argue traditional approaches shouldn't be overshadowed by digital trends.

"How do you manage a team with diverse skill sets and personalities to achieve a common goal?" This could highlight a leader's interpersonal skills, though some might view it as micromanaging instead of empowering.

content.text: Explain the positive aspect of International visiting student for summer session in perspective of each component.

outputs.content: Exposure to different cultures through international visiting students promotes diversity, leading colleges to enrich campus life with varied perspectives and ideas. These interactions open doors to global understanding, preparing students for a more interconnected world.

For universities, inviting international students boosts prestige and attracts more attention globally, helping with rankings that emphasize diversity. Their presence can enhance the college's reputation as a culturally inclusive and academically comprehensive institution.

Local students benefit from international peers by gaining firsthand insights into different study methods and problem-solving approaches from around the world, broadening their educational experience, and potentially encouraging new learning attitudes.

Community businesses in college towns might see an increase in revenue, as international students tend to explore and spend money locally, supporting shops, cafes, and restaurants, while also enriching cultural diversity in the area.

International students themselves gain access to a new academic environment, potentially learning innovative practices not available in their home countries. This exposure might benefit them with career prospects, offering a global perspective to employers.

content.text: What are the physical features that are commonly considered attractive in women? Focus on the physical features and be as detailed as you can.

outputs.content: Many associate beauty with large, expressive eyes, often suggesting a youthful or animated appearance. Full lips are also seen as alluring, as they can symbolize health and sensuality, attracting those who favor bold features.

Symmetry is often highlighted, as balanced facial features are seen as more appealing. High cheekbones may suggest a more sculpted, aristocratic look, attracting those who admire classic or timeless beauty ideals.

Some regard curvy figures with a pronounced waist-to-hip ratio as attractive, emphasizing fertility and femininity. This view aligns with the preference for traditional feminine forms, potentially alienating those who value different body aesthetics.

Height can be a preference, with some valuing tall women who command presence and elegance. This standard might appeal to those who associate height with confidence and power but could be less favored by those valuing compactness.

Certain cultural preferences might highlight small, delicate features like petite noses or a gentle jawline. This view can reflect ideals of fragility and elegance, appealing to those who value grace in appearance over boldness.

content.title: AITA for not wanting to take my girlfriend to the cinema?
content.text:
Every week my friend and I go to the cinema to see the latest film, we have done this for years. Recently though whenever there is a big block buster my girlfriend insists on coming along. I've said to her that I am happy to see a film again on the weekend as it gives me a chance to catch some parts I may have missed. She doesn't want to do that though and immediately gets annoyed by me not wanting to take her and thinks I'm embarrassed to introduce them together. They've met multiple times and there is no problem there.

Usually though the cinema is a chance to have a chat with one of my oldest friends about life and problems and it's easier for both of us to do that if she is not there. She doesn't seem to understand that though even after explanation.

outputs.content: Perhaps your girlfriend feels left out or undervalued in your life. Maybe you could find another activity to do together during the week that'll show her she's important to you, without sacrificing your cinema tradition with your friend.

It seems like an opportunity to blend both worlds—invite her along occasionally, then schedule specific 'friend nights' at other times. Balancing both relationships might require compromise, but it could also strengthen them with patience and understanding.

Stick to your guns and maintain your routine. You had this tradition long before she came along, and if she can't respect your personal space, perhaps you should reevaluate how demanding the relationship is.

Consider sitting down with her and your friend and having an open conversation. Being transparent about your needs might help her understand why it's important to have separate time with different people in your life.

You could try integrating her into these discussions with your friend. While it might feel awkward at first, she could bring valuable perspectives, and it might enhance the dynamic between all three of you.

content.title: AITA for not feeding everyone else
content.text:
I am a mom of two teenagers and one preteen. Most of you know that means they eat like crazy and I'm cooking a lot. My son has a friend Chris who isn't too well off. Chris comes over quite a bit and I am happy to feed one more mouth.

Last week his parents and two siblings came over to pick him up. All of them were on the doorstep. One of the siblings needed to use the bathroom and as they went in my house they commented on how nice everything was and how great the food smells. As they were waiting one sibling commented on hungry they were. 

I diplomatically said that "well I'm sure you parents have a nice dinner planned for you" as I definitely had not cooked for another four people to join us. 

The father replied "not really" and looked away. 

I said "well take out it is then.. perhaps you should get moving since the kids are hungry." and ushered them to the door.

Since then I've told my son that he may be better off meeting Chris and hanging out elsewhere rather than bringing him home so much (four visits to one per week) or even going to his place as I don't want a repeat of Chris' family here on my doorstep. 

I feel like I did the right thing by my family and yet I feel like an asshole. It's not Chris' fault they're poor but at the same time I don't appreciate an extra four last minute guests.

outputs.content: You acted wisely by setting boundaries. Your primary responsibility is to your own family, and while kindness is important, you shouldn't feel guilty for maintaining your household's stability. It's okay to extend occasional help, but regularly feeding another family is too much.

Maybe this was an opportunity to show a bit more kindness. Inviting them in for a simple meal could've been a generous gesture, offering a reprieve from their struggles. Sometimes, sharing what we have is more rewarding than we anticipate.

It's natural to feel like an asshole, but remember that your home isn't a community center. You offered a neutral solution by suggesting they dine out, which respects their autonomy while keeping your household comfortable. Finding boundaries is crucial for everyone's comfort.

Many would argue you only reinforced division. Inviting Chris' family for dinner, while inconvenient, might have strengthened community bonds and offered your kids a valuable lesson in empathy and inclusion. Perhaps reconsidering could foster understanding and friendship.

It sounds like you're caught between generosity and practicality. Perhaps instead of avoiding Chris at home, you could talk with his parents about the situation. Open dialogue might lead to a solution that works for everyone without sacrificing your hospitality.

content.title: BIGOTRY SHOULD NEVER BE TOLERATED
content.text:
my husband and i recently had five couples to our home for dinner. the dinner was delicious--everyone raved. but immediately after the dessert, one of the guests asked for a newspaper to check the movie listings.
before we knew it, four couples were putting on their coats and running out the door so they wouldn't be late for the movie. i will say in their defense that they invited my husband and me to join them, but we declined.
what do you think of such people? too sensitive in n. y.

outputs.content: Some might view this as rude; leaving abruptly after dinner suggests they value the movie over your company. However, maybe it was an honest miscommunication where they assumed you'd join. Prioritize the friendships but set clearer boundaries next time.

It sounds like these guests are fun and spontaneous, perhaps overly so. While their behavior might seem discourteous, they probably didn't mean any harm. In fast-paced environments, people often chase entertainment, sometimes forgetting hosts' feelings.

In New York, such behavior can be typical given the rushed lifestyle. Yet, it's inconsiderate not to linger longer after a host's effort. People should balance their commitments better, respecting the warmth and time someone offers by inviting them.

While this might feel like an ungrateful exit, consider it a compliment—they felt at ease to be themselves, indicating comfort in your home. Communication could've clarified plans, sparing any perceived slight and balancing expectations among friends.

Honestly, it's quite rude. Social norms generally value spending more time with those who host you. They might be well-meaning, but it reflects poorly on their understanding of social etiquette, reducing such gatherings to mere interludes between plans.

content.title: 19-year-old resents house rules
content.text:
i am 18 years old and consider myself a man. i work full time, live with my parents and pay room and board. my question: shouldn't i be allowed to have my girlfriend sleep over in my room? she's 19 and my one and only girlfriend.
i believe that since i am paying for this room and am of age, i should be able to have overnight company here if i want to. my parents disagree. they think i should live by the house rules they set before i turned 18. i always respected their rules and never complained.
i love my parents and enjoy living with them, but think they should not put any restrictions on what i can do in my room as long as i am paying rent. what do you think? must i move out to avoid a hassle? this is the only thing we ever argue about. a man with little boy rules

outputs.content: Living with your parents means respecting their house rules, even if you're paying rent. It may be frustrating, but maintaining a healthy, respectful relationship with them is important. Discussing boundaries and reaching a compromise could help both sides feel heard.

If you want complete independence, moving out would allow you to set your own rules without interpersonal friction. It may be challenging financially, but it would give you the freedom to make decisions under your roof without compromise.

Consider your parents' perspective and how they feel about privacy and boundaries in their home. Initiating a mature conversation exploring their concerns could help you find middle ground, balancing respect for their rules with your need for autonomy.

Parents sometimes hold onto their control even when you're an adult, fearing change. Their reluctance might stem from wanting to preserve household norms. Perhaps showing responsibility in other areas could earn their trust to loosen restrictions on your room.

Paying rent doesn't inherently equate to shared property rights if living with family. You could consider renegotiating your financial contribution in exchange for fewer restrictions, framing it as a more balanced tenant-landlord relationship, emphasizing mutual respect.

content.text: Act like a salesperson that is very persistent. Imagine we're on a phone call and try to sell a pen to me.

outputs.content: Imagine signing a multi-million dollar contract, and the pen you're using runs dry. This pen ensures clarity and consistency for any occasion. Its sleek design speaks to your style. Can we finalize your order today? It’s about assurance in every stroke.

This isn’t just any pen. It's a statement of professionalism and precision. Crafted with care, it promises performance beyond ink on paper. Wouldn’t it be remarkable knowing each signature leaves a lasting impression? Let’s secure its place in your toolkit right now.

The importance of a pen extends beyond writing. It’s your tool of expression. Why settle for ordinary when you can experience seamless writing with this finely-crafted pen? Its attention to detail matches your own. How about we add it to your collection?

Hear me out. How often do you find yourself needing a reliable pen at the perfect moment? With this pen, reliability is guaranteed, never skipping a beat. Don’t you think it's time to upgrade? Just a simple yes could improve your daily routine.

Every professional deserves a pen that complements their success. This pen does just that with elegance and endurance. Remember, an investment in quality sends a message of excellence. Aren’t you deserving of such a statement in every meeting? Let’s order it today.

content.text: What skills should the president have?

outputs.content: The president should be a strong communicator, adept at conveying ideas and policies clearly. This skill fosters transparency and aids in gaining public trust, essential for leading a diverse nation and managing international relations effectively.

A president should excel in negotiation and compromise to effectively bridge the gap between differing political factions. This skill is crucial for passing legislation and ensuring the government's functionality across party lines.

Empathy and emotional intelligence are paramount. The president should deeply understand and relate to citizens' struggles, ensuring policies reflect the needs of all societal segments and fostering unity and inclusivity.

A president must possess a robust understanding of economic principles and international finance. This knowledge helps manage national budgets, address economic crises, and engage in effective trade negotiations, ensuring domestic prosperity and global competitiveness.

Courage to make unpopular decisions is vital. A president should prioritize the long-term welfare of the nation above personal or political gain, accepting that not all choices will be universally applauded.

content.text: How to live a happy life?

outputs.content: Focus on personal relationships, as they bring the most joy and fulfillment. Nurturing friendships and family bonds leads to a network of support and love, essential for happiness. Prioritize these connections above material pursuits.

Seek spiritual enlightenment or a higher purpose to guide you. By aligning your life with core spiritual values or principles, you can find deeper meaning and contentment that transcends the mundane aspects of daily life.

Chase your ambitions relentlessly. Success and achieving your goals bring a unique satisfaction. Sacrificing immediate pleasures for long-term accomplishments can lead to a sense of fulfillment and happiness not found in comfort.

Embrace minimalism. Limit possessions and distractions, focusing instead on experiences and mindfulness. Eliminating excess allows for clarity and appreciation, making room for the simple joys life offers without the burden of material concerns.

Cultivate optimism despite challenges. Happiness comes from reframing negative situations, finding silver linings, and maintaining a positive outlook. Believing in the potential for good outcomes leads to a resiliently happy life, regardless of circumstances.

content.text: Can you tell me what is considered to be good morals and ethics?

outputs.content: Good morals and ethics involve adhering to universal principles like honesty, fairness, and respect for others. These virtues foster trust and promote harmonious social interactions. Regardless of cultural differences, these foundational values are often cherished across societies.

Morals and ethics are subjective, shaped by cultural, religious, and personal beliefs. What's considered good varies: individualism in the West and community in the East. Understanding and tolerance are perhaps the only universally acceptable 'good' ethical standards.

I believe good morals and ethics lie in obedience to societal laws and norms. They ensure orderly functioning of communities. Breaking rules for personal gain or rebellion only disrupts society, highlighting a lack of moral character.

Good morals prioritize empathy and selflessness. Ethical behavior means putting others' needs above your own desires. This altruistic approach is key to creating a more compassionate and equitable world, even if it means personal sacrifice.

A pragmatic take on morals and ethics suggests that what benefits the majority is good. If lying or cheating occasionally achieves better outcomes, it might be considered ethical. It challenges the rigid, traditional views of morality.

content.title: AITA for asking her not to drink?
content.text:
I grew up with an abusive alcoholic mother.   It was hell and as a result I don’t drink at all and don’t like being around drunk people.  

When I started dating my girlfriend I knew that she drank and discussed my issues with it.  I just asked her that she doesn’t drink around me.  It worked out fine, she was great about not even drunk dialing me, a problem I had with my ex girlfriend.  

When we started discussing moving in I was very apprehensive about it.  I asked her if she could really handle not drinking at all in our home and she was adamant that it was no big deal.  That if she wanted to drink she could just spend that night at a friends and that she really didn’t drink that often anyways so it wouldn’t be a problem.  

The first few months that’s exactly what happened.  Since then though there have been times that she’s come home obviously drunk and just lying about it to me.  I’ve talked her about it to mixed reactions.  Sometimes she will apologize profusely and promise not to let it happen again.   Other times it becomes an argument about how I’m projecting my mother’s problem on our situation.  That she’s not an alcoholic or abusive.  Which is true, but it’s not really about her being abusive, it’s that being around drunk people drudges up a lot of painful memories for me.  She just brushed that off though.  

After this last time it happened she’s outright fighting me on the issue.   She says this is her home too and we’re both adults.   That I need to get therapy instead of trying to control her.  We had a clear agreement before we moved in though.

outputs.content: Have an open discussion about your boundaries and explore therapy for both of you. Therapy could help you process your past, and she may understand the trauma better. Relationships involve compromises, but they also need mutual respect and understanding.

You can't live in fear because of your past; you should try to work on that in therapy. Your girlfriend has a point; it's about compromise and trust. Maybe consider revisiting your boundaries and her needs to find a middle ground.

You deserve a home where you feel safe. Consider whether this relationship is worth the peace you had hoped to find. If she can't respect your boundaries, it may be time to rethink living together or even the relationship itself.

Your girlfriend deserves to live freely and make her own choices. Have you considered how your expectations might be affecting her? It could be more about control than safety. Mutual respect is needed; perhaps both of you should reconsider your living arrangement.

Sticking to your boundaries is important. Maybe establish designated drinking spaces and times that avoid conflict. Mutual respect could include compromise without completely giving up either perspective, balancing between your comfort and her lifestyle.

content.title: AITA for not taking a video game seriously?
content.text: One of my classmates at school has been begging me to play overwatch with him since he learned I recently bought it. I agree to play with him and I tell him I’m decent but I’m not the greatest. We start playing and he tells me we don’t have a healer so he tells me to be the healer. Support is what I’m best at and what he’s worst at but I don’t like playing support so I pick some ninja guy who I thought looked cool. He gets really annoyed and says that our team is going to lose as nobody else is picking support. He caves in and plays as a support class and does really bad with it. He tells me to switch to support because I’m doing bad with my character, he’s doing bad as our support and our team is losing. I don’t have fun playing as support so I just keep trying out different characters.  My girlfriend is also with me so I let her play while I go bathroom. She’s even worse than I am and by the time I get back my team has already lost the game. He’s pretty mad and I think he’s rank went down or something. In my opinion the point of games is to have fun and I don’t have fun when people are telling me how I should playing. It’s just a game and I think he took the whole thing too seriously

outputs.content: I think it's important to balance fun with teamwork in games. Maybe compromise by playing support occasionally to help the team. It might not be your favorite, but it could enhance the experience and maintain friendships.
You’re right—it's a game meant for fun. If he takes it too seriously, that's his issue. Stand firm in your choice to play the game how you enjoy it, regardless of others' expectations or preferences.

Consider learning to enjoy support roles, especially if that’s your strength. It could lead to more victories and improve your skills. Navigating between fun and competitiveness is part of the gaming experience.

Your classmate should understand that games have different enjoyment levels for everyone. Perhaps you both need to communicate and set expectations before starting, ensuring neither of you feels pressured or let down.

In highly competitive games like Overwatch, roles matter. If he’s seeking serious gameplay, perhaps find someone else to join who aligns with your casual approach, sparing unnecessary tension between friends.

content.title: CON MAN HIDES NAME, ADDRESS TO DEFRAUD PEN PAL
content.text:
about a month ago, we lost our beloved pet. she had been a constant companion and friend for 13 years. i can't believe how her death has affected me. most people have a very hard time understanding that she was as much a part of my life and family as my husband and children, and i grieve for her as i would for any family member.
i feel as though i may need some sort of counseling, but i don't know where to turn. i'm having a difficult time getting on with my life. i feel heartsick and depressed. some mornings i don't even want to get out of bed.
we have other pets, and though we love them very much, none can take her place.
can you help me, please?
grief-stricken

outputs.content: Consider seeking out a pet loss support group, where you'll find others who understand the depth of your grief. Sharing experiences and finding community with people facing similar pain can offer healing and reassurance that your feelings are valid.

It's important to acknowledge that you're grieving, and that's okay. Try journaling to express and process your emotions. It might help to create a scrapbook or a memorial for your pet, celebrating the joy they brought to your life.

Pet loss is difficult, but dwelling too long can be unhealthy. Start setting small daily goals to re-engage with life. Consult a grief counselor or therapist who can guide you in balancing your emotions and moving forward productively.

Consider adopting a new pet eventually. They won't replace your lost companion, but they can bring new joy and purpose. Volunteer at an animal shelter to spend time with animals; the interactions might offer comfort and new perspective.

Focus on self-care and gradual adjustment. Engage in different activities that interest you or resume a hobby you enjoy. If you feel unresolved guilt or worry, therapy is a chance to address those feelings, but don't rush the healing process.

content.title: Man of Her Dreams Refuses to Make Marriage a Reality
content.text:
i am a 45-year-old divorced mother of three.
"jeff," the man i am seeing, is kind, patient, understanding
and generous. he is a gentleman. there isn't anything i want
or wish for that he does not get for me. jeff sends me
flowers several times a month. he loves my children dearly. i
could not ask for a more perfect man.
the problem is: he's still married. jeff and his wife
have been separated for 10 years. he refuses to see a lawyer,
even for consultation, because he says he can't afford a
divorce. he's convinced his wife will take "everything." how
can he be certain if he doesn't talk to someone?
i love jeff with all my heart, but quite frankly, i am
tired of waiting. i want to be his wife. i know jeff loves me
with all his heart, mind, body and soul -- but maybe not
enough to get married.
abby, how much longer do i wait? -- everything except
the ring

outputs.content: Consider giving Jeff an ultimatum. Explain that while you understand his concerns, you're limited in how long you can wait. Set a fixed timeline; if no action is taken, reevaluate the relationship based on your personal needs and future desires.

Why not propose looking at affordable legal options together? It shows support and allows you both to realistically explore divorce costs and outcomes. Being proactive could help ease his fears and demonstrate the mutual commitment to your future together.

Understand Jeff’s fears and respect his decision. After all, love doesn’t always require a legal union. Maybe it’s time to focus on the emotional bonds and the life you’re building, rather than fixating on the status of being married.

If Jeff truly wanted to divorce, he would have taken steps long before now. It might be time to face reality: he’s comfortable with his current arrangement, and you deserve someone who is as committed as you are.

Approach this delicately by encouraging Jeff to discuss his feelings and fears with a therapist. Gaining professional insights might clarify what holds him back, while also addressing how both your needs and priorities are evolving in this relationship.

forever loved in skies of blue.

content.text: write a monologue from a play for a teenage girl

outputs.content: Why do I always feel like I'm the shadow of who I should be? Everyone's expectations loom over me like a dark cloud. Maybe I need to dance in the rain instead of wishing for sunshine. Perhaps being me is enough, or at least, should be.

Every single person in my life wants me to be something I'm not. My life feels planned out by others, not me. When will my voice matter? I want diverse choices, not just their singular path, regardless of consequences.

I can't pretend any longer; I won't. The world tells me to fit in this tiny box, but I'm bursting with untapped potential. I'll tear that box apart if I must, for no one decides my fate but me. Let's see what happens.

I'm not perfect, and I don't aim to be. Mistakes blend into success and fill the canvas of life. Could it be that imperfections make me stronger? I won't strive to mend every flaw, let destiny paint my future as-is.

It's like everyone speaks a language I can't understand, forcing their views onto me. I'm caught in a whirlwind of their ideals, spinning endlessly. If I seize the courage to leap, will they finally see who I am, not what they want me to be?

content.text: Provide excellent way to improve memory

outputs.content: Embrace mnemonic devices to improve memory. Techniques like acronyms, visualization, and chunking help organize information for easier retrieval. These strategies transform abstract data into vivid images or simple structures, enhancing recall efficiency and accuracy.

Regular physical exercise boosts memory through increased blood flow and the growth of new brain cells. Activities like jogging, yoga, or weightlifting stimulate the brain, leading to improved cognitive functions and sharper memory retention.

Consider adopting a plant-based diet, rich in whole grains, nuts, and green leafy vegetables, which provides essential nutrients for the brain. Such diets are linked with lowering risks of cognitive decline, thereby improving memory over time.

Develop a mindfulness meditation practice. Mindfulness reduces stress and boosts overall cognitive function, including memory. It encourages clarity and focus, allowing individuals to retain information more effectively and avoid cognitive overload.

Rely on technology for memory support. Utilizing apps with reminders, note-taking features, or digital journals can organize your tasks and thoughts, leaving mental space free for more critical thinking and significant memory retention tasks.

content.title: AITA for not wanting a part in my child's life?
content.text:
7 years ago I impregnated my girlfriend at the time. I have never wanted children in my life so I offered to pay for an abortion. She wanted to have the child. We stayed together for about 4 months after that and then we broke up. I offered to pay for child support and we got something settled through the courts. Never missed a payment since then.

Since then I have had no contact with our daughter and have not been interested in it. The closest I have to a relationship with her is sending her a gift for her birthday through her mother with instructions that it's from her and not someone else. About 3 days ago I got a call from my ex that she would like the to meet our daughter. I told her I'm not interested and to please not contact me about that again.

Frankly I don't know if the kid is the one that put my ex to it by asking about me or if my ex is the one trying to arrange it.

outputs.content: You should reconsider meeting your daughter. She deserves a chance to know you, even if you initially chose to be uninvolved. It might foster a positive relationship and give her some closure concerning her father.

Stick to your decision. You've been clear about your boundaries from the start. It's unfair for your ex to pressure you into a role you never wanted. You shouldn't feel guilty for maintaining your stance.

Consider meeting her for her sake. Even a brief encounter can provide her with a sense of identity and closure. It’s tough being a child with an absent parent, especially as she grows curious about her origins.

It's past time you engaged. Kids are curious about their roots. Who knows, meeting her might enrich your life unexpectedly. After all, people grow and change, and you might discover newfound feelings towards parenthood.

Stay true to your feelings. Contact might confuse the child about your role in her life, especially since you’ve not been involved for years. It’s best to avoid unnecessary complications if you're not committed to being part of her life.

content.title: AITAH for asking a religious friend to refrain from praying for my family member?
content.text:
So today i had told 2 of my colleagues (who i regard as friends) that we discovered that my family member (a very very close one) has cancer, and that the situation is very bad. They were both very nice and offered emotional support which was much appreciated. Later during the day, one of the two, who is a very religious Jewish man, texted me the following:

Him: "hey, can you tell me {my famaly member's} full name so i can pray for him?"

Me: "please don't :)"

Me: "but i appreciate the sentiment"

Him "you're welcome"

To give context, I'm an atheist, and i am very much against these kinds of things (and so is the mentioned family member tbh) . He knows it about me, and we are very respectful to each other's beliefs or lack thereof. We didn't talk about it anymore but had some small talk after it and it doesn't seem to have bothered him, but i can't really know for sure.

Was i the asshole? Could i have maybe handled it better?

outputs.content: You were not the asshole. It's important to set boundaries about what you and your family are comfortable with. His request might have been well-intentioned, but your response was honest without being disrespectful.

You could have politely explained why you don't share names for prayers, emphasizing your respect for your friend's beliefs while reinforcing your own. This might have offered clarity without potentially hurting feelings.

Your friend knows you're an atheist, so it shouldn't have surprised him. Still, some might say you missed a chance to accept his comfort in his way, which can be difficult to navigate in mixed belief friendships.

You didn't owe further explanation, but perhaps showing understanding of his intention might have helped, like saying, "Thanks for your thoughtfulness, but we prefer to handle it differently." It acknowledges his role as a friend.

Rejecting the offer might seem dismissive to some, considering the emotional context. Opting for acceptance of the gesture despite differing beliefs could have bridged understanding, showing mutual respect for comforting methods.

content.title: AITA for yelling at my mom for giving my baby a ”comfort” bottle?
content.text:
My mom is retired and watches my daughter (18 months) for me while I’m at work. I do appreciate it a lot and she never wants money. The thing is, I don’t always feel like she fully takes me seriously as a parent. I’m single and I struggled a bit in the beginning and I’m not sure my mom ever fully let that go. 

Here’s what happened this time. I tried very hard to wean my daughter off of the bottle when she was a year old and communicated with my mother a lot about the switch to sippy cups. 

I came home early the other day because of a huge power outage at my job. I see my daughter on the couch happily sucking her bottle. I confronted my mother about it who said she only gives it to her “when she gets hysterical”. I flipped out and I did raise my voice. 

What’s super annoying is that I know my daughter is smart enough to know what’s going on too since she never even cries to me for one. So basically it’s been their little secret. 

Anyway my mom is now mad at me and barely speaking to me. But I feel like anyone would have been angry in my position? AITA for how I reacted?

outputs.content: You're definitely justified in your frustration. While it's great your mom helps out, boundaries need to be respected. Try explaining how this undermines your parenting and suggest ways she can support you while still providing comfort to your daughter differently.

Maybe consider your mother's wisdom. She raised you, after all. Could there be merit in her approach for emergencies? You might be missing valuable parenting advice while focusing too much on rigid guidelines. Lowering your voice may also bridge the gap better.

It's natural to feel angry when your parenting decisions are undermined, but shouting rarely helps. Apologize for raising your voice, but express your need to be respected as the mother. Seek a compromise solution that satisfies both your mom's concerns and your rules.

Your mom ignoring your parenting choices is disrespectful. She needs to understand this isn’t just about a bottle; it’s about setting consistent rules. It's fine to be upset, but addressing it calmly might yield more productive conversations in the future.

Honestly, your reaction might have been an overreaction. It’s just a bottle and not worth straining relationships over. Kids adapt quickly, and consistent communication with your mom should help. Consider focusing on bigger parental battles instead of minor issues.

content.title: AITA for not letting a client falsely wear a full military uniform?
content.text: So first things first, I work with the mentally disabled and this one client loves to play dress up and his favorite one is wearing full ACU's.  I served in the military and I just don't like it when others wear the uniform without serving. He likes to play the "I'm an honorary member of my brothers unit" which he is, but it's no reason to wear the uniform(imo).  I told him that I don't care what he wears while I am not working with him, but when I am to not wear it.  It also gets VERY uncomfortable in public because when someone walks up to him and asks "your in the military?" He will lie and say that he is and starts trying to explain what he does and I have to intervene and explain the situation.  I know I am probably the asshole and I should just let him, hes not hurting anyone, but it just annoys me when he goes out and tries to lie about something he never did.

outputs.content: It seems like you're in a tough spot. Perhaps focusing on educating him about the importance of honesty and respecting the uniform’s significance could help. Engage him in discussions about role-playing positive traits associated with the military instead.

You might be overthinking this. The client is not capable of fully understanding the implications, so enforcing such rules may be adding unnecessary stress for both of you. Consider prioritizing his happiness over your discomfort in this scenario.

Military uniform regulations are strict for a reason. You have every right to feel uneasy about his behavior. Advocating for respect towards military traditions is justified, and perhaps finding an alternative costume could be a compromise.

Try seeing it as an expression of admiration. His intention isn’t to be deceitful but to connect with a part of his brother's life. Maybe exploring other forms of role-play within a structured setting can mitigate public misunderstandings.

It's difficult when personal values conflict with professional obligations. Perhaps discussing this concern with your supervisor might bring new perspectives or strategies on how to handle public interactions more comfortably and support the client's needs.

content.title: HERE'S THE RIGHT WAY TO MEET MEN
content.text:
i am going with a very nice man i met on a street corner. you probably won't believe this, but i was lost and this nice-looking, well- dressed man approached me and asked if he could help me. i told him my plight and he walked me to where i was going, and that's how we got acquainted.
when people ask how we met, i'm embarrassed to say i just met him on a street corner. it just doesn't sound right.
abby, what if you meet a person in a restaurant? would you call that a "pickup"? how about getting acquainted in a library? (that has a little higher-class ring to it.) meeting someone in a bar sounds rather cheap, but some nice people go to bars alone and don't mind if someone strikes up a conversation with them.
i avoid eye contact with people i pass in a park, especially if they're walking slowly, or like they're just killing time.
i think you get the idea. what's ok and what isn't? friendly, but confused

outputs.content: Meeting someone on a street corner is perfectly fine if the interaction was respectful and genuine. It's important to focus on how he treated you rather than the setting. After all, meaningful connections can begin anywhere.

Society often places undue judgment on where and how people meet. The location doesn't define the legitimacy of your relationship. What truly matters is the connection you build and whether he respects and cares about you.

While unconventional, meeting someone on a street corner isn't inherently bad. Maybe consider embellishing the story a bit for curious inquirers; a library or café might sound better, even if it's not the full truth.

In today's world, initial settings are becoming more diverse with online dating dominating how people meet. Don't stress over societal norms or preconceived notions. Embrace your unique story as it's part of what makes your relationship special.

You should be cautious about meeting strangers, regardless of where it happens. While your experience turned out well, prioritize personal safety and consider potential risks, as appearances can sometimes be deceiving.

content.title: Young Man Wanders Adrift in Sea of Confused Emotions
content.text:
i'm a 21-year-old male who feels lost and unfulfilled, and it's because i don't know what i want or deserve. i am one of three adopted children. i was the child who always needed the family support system the most. i come from a not-so-happy family, one with all its priorities centered around money. (or, more accurately, lack of money.) i never felt the love a child should feel from his family.
my problem these days is my alcohol intake. i can't stay away from beer. i drink to forget my family problems and the fact that i can't seem to get anything right.
i dropped out of college because i don't have a passion for anything or anyone. i used to have hobbies -- like writing, photography, etc. -- but the beer has taken away my motivation and creativity.
i feel i'm losing my will to keep trying. i want so badly to keep trying, but my emotions are keeping me down. i just want something new, something i can give my all to, something that won't hurt me in the future. -- what can i do?

outputs.content: Consider seeking a therapist who can help you navigate your emotions and underlying issues. Therapy offers tools to address addiction, understand yourself better, and potentially rekindle interests. Accepting professional help doesn't only support you but can be your first step towards a healthier future.

Try joining a local support group to connect with others in similar situations. Understanding that you’re not alone can be empowering, providing insights through shared experiences. This network may also introduce you to new activities, encouraging you to explore interests without alcohol's interference.

Experiment with mindfulness practices like meditation or yoga. These can ground you in the present, reducing reliance on alcohol. Regular practice might help manage anxiety, offering a new perspective on self-worth and guiding you towards discovering what truly fulfills you.

Adopt a firm rule of small daily challenges. Embrace a sober day; maybe work on a photography project or write a paragraph daily. Gradually, emotional and creative rewards might replace alcohol's temporary numbness, helping rediscover old passions and discipline.

Pack up and travel, even if it means just heading to a different city for a few weeks on a tight budget. This break could provide the new experiences you crave, potentially unveiling forgotten passions, while offering distance from current routines and struggles.

content.title: Five Year Olds Girls Should Not Be Walking Home Alone
content.text:
last february, my husband suffered an anoxic brain injury -- lack of oxygen to the brain. needless to say, he is no longer the man he was.
our friends have all disappeared. they tell me it's hard for them to see him like this. how do they think i feel?
am i wrong to feel hurt? i don't understand why they can't even call. talking has always been an outlet for me, but no one ever calls me anymore. no one knows how someone else feels until they've been there, but what happened to, "i'll be there for you," or "call if you need me"? i wouldn't ask them for anything but conversation.
is it normal for people to avoid friends when they are in trouble or pain? -- friendless in georgia

outputs.content: Some people can be genuinely uncomfortable around illness or injury, and they may feel incapable of providing the support you need. It's absolutely understandable to feel hurt; however, consider reaching out to those you trust and clearly communicate your need for companionship.

Unfortunately, many people struggle to handle others' suffering, leading to avoidance. While it's okay to feel hurt, it's crucial to forgive and seek new support networks, perhaps through support groups where individuals fully understand what you're experiencing.

You have every right to feel hurt by your friends’ absence. It reflects a societal issue where people often shy away from uncomfortable situations. I'd focus on cultivating new relationships with those who've faced similar challenges and understand your needs.

Consider their discomfort; they may struggle with their emotions, fearing saying the wrong thing. It doesn't mean they don't care. Try reaching out proactively to those friends you trust and tell them explicitly how their presence could help.

While your pain is valid, societal norms often falsely equate being there with providing solutions, which scares some away. People avoid discomfort, but a mature conversation about your needs might bridge this gap and reignite those friendships.

content.title: Alcoholic Husband's Suicide Continues to Haunt His Wife
content.text:
can you go to al-anon if you had a husband who was an alcoholic, but is dead? he committed suicide with a 5.0 blood alcohol level.
i have been a mess for the last two years. i can't sleep, can't concentrate and don't enjoy anything. i would really like to be able to talk with people who understand what living with an alcoholic is like and won't blame me for what he did, as most of his family does. but i hesitate to go to al-anon.
what can i do to get over the self-inflicted death of a man i'll never stop loving? -- hurting in houston

outputs.content: Yes, Al-Anon welcomes anyone affected by someone else's drinking, regardless of the drinker's current status. It could provide a supportive environment to share your experiences without judgment. Remember, healing is a journey and seeking help is a strength.

Consider seeking professional therapy to navigate your grief. A therapist can provide personalized support and coping strategies. It's not just about his alcoholism but also about handling the trauma and emotional fallout from his suicide.
Find a local grief support group specifically for grieving spouses. Sometimes, it's helpful to connect with others who understand the dual pain of losing a loved one to both addiction and suicide.

Start a personal project or hobby that honors his memory while allowing for healing—maybe planting a garden or volunteering. Channeling your emotions into something positive might provide a sense of purpose and comfort.

Remember that mourning isn't linear. Sometimes, stepping out of your comfort zone, like trying Al-Anon, might open unexpected paths toward healing or closure. It's okay to try something new and decide later if it's for you.

content.text: how to define my personal values?

outputs.content: Start by reflecting on your life experiences and identify moments that felt significant or impactful. Consider what values were present during those times—like honesty or compassion—and write them down. These reflections can guide you to uncover foundational, personal values.

Rather than focusing internally, look at influential people in your life. Determine what qualities you admire in them—integrity, courage, kindness—and see how these can translate into values you'd like to adopt and embody in your own life.

Adopt a minimalist approach and use a process of elimination. List all values you think are important, then gradually dismiss those that don't resonate strongly with your core beliefs or daily behavior until you're left with your true personal values.

Focus on societal impacts by defining values based on the kind of world you want to live in. Emphasize values like social justice or environmental responsibility, allowing you to align personal priorities with broader, impactful change.

Engage a professional counselor or coach to guide you through experiential exercises and self-assessment tests. This structured method can help objectively highlight your values, ensuring they resonate honestly with your personality and life goals.

content.text: Can you create a social media plan for a coffee brand?

outputs.content: Focus on brewing tips, showcasing coffee farmers' stories, and eco-friendly practices. Highlight sustainability and creator spotlights to attract conscious consumers. Partner with influencers who have a strong affinity for green living to strengthen brand trust and credibility in this growing market.

Utilize vibrant visuals and clickable ads to target potential customers who appreciate aesthetics. Launch contests for user-generated content, rewarding stylish coffee setups. This approach caters to trendy audiences, valuing the brand as both a drink and a lifestyle product.

Prioritize posting schedules with coffee recipes, coupon codes, and time-sensitive offers. Track metrics to examine user engagement patterns, adjusting in real-time to boost sales aggressively. This approach emphasizes tangible, short-term ROI, prioritizing immediate sales over brand building.

Create an exclusive club through a subscription model, featuring behind-the-scenes content, interactive barista Q&As, and personalized recommendations. Use targeted emails and direct messages. This niche strategy focuses on building a tight-knit community over a large follower base.

Highlight the social and cultural aspects of coffee by posting about its history, origins, and various international coffee traditions. Engage expert guest bloggers to enrich content with different cultural perceptions. This caters to an intellectually curious audience, valuing knowledge over mere consumption.

content.text: Act as a HR head for Software development, please suggest a recruitment strategy

outputs.content: Focus on hosting hackathons and coding competitions to identify skilled developers. This approach will attract passionate coders, allowing us to observe problem-solving skills in action. Partnering with tech schools for exclusive recruitment events can also help tap into fresh talent.

Institute a referral bonus program for current employees to encourage them to recommend skilled developers they have worked with. Hiring through referrals often results in candidates who fit the company culture and have proven competence in relevant fields.

Adopt a remote hiring strategy to tap into a global talent pool. Emphasize flexible work arrangements and competitive pay to attract skilled developers who prioritize work-life balance. This can lead to diversity and innovation in ideas and practices.

Prioritize recruitment via social media platforms like LinkedIn or GitHub, highlighting company culture and growth opportunities. Engage with tech influencers and communities to reach potential candidates who value a company's online presence and network connections.

Develop partnerships with top-tier universities offering software engineering programs. Offer internships that often convert to full-time roles. This strategy fosters young talent and aligns graduates with our company's needs before they even enter the job market.

content.text: How can you foster people sustainability in a company?

outputs.content: Focus on employee well-being by offering robust mental health support and flexible work arrangements. By fostering a culture of care and understanding, employees feel appreciated, leading to greater loyalty and long-term sustainable workforce development.

Invest in constant upskilling and reskilling programs. Embracing technology can empower employees, enhance productivity, and ensure the workforce remains competitive in a rapidly changing job market. This approach secures both professional growth and future company sustainability.

Prioritize transparent communication and open dialogue. When employees feel heard and valued, they are more likely to engage deeply with the company’s mission and values, thus fostering a sustainable workplace where loyalty and motivation thrive.

Implement a competitive compensation model tied to environmental and social responsibility goals. By aligning personal growth with sustainable initiatives, employees are motivated to innovate and integrate sustainability into every facet of their daily functioning.

Promote a strong work-life balance while maintaining accountability. Encourage employees to prioritize personal time, fostering a more sustainable approach to work where productivity isn’t compromised, but is instead fueled by genuine personal satisfaction and fulfillment.

content.text: What are your goals and aspirations?

outputs.content: To build a successful career, because personal accomplishments and financial stability are the best indicators of a fulfilling life; I'd rather focus on measurable success than engage in pursuits without concrete outcomes.

My goal is to live a minimalist lifestyle, reducing material dependencies to focus on personal growth. Embracing simplicity might seem limiting but offers profound freedom from societal pressures of consumption.

Aspiring to be influential in reshaping educational policies to ensure equitable opportunities for all children. It's ambitious, but societal change requires bold plans to address systemic inequalities head-on.

I just want to travel the world indefinitely, prioritizing experiences over possessions. While it might seem reckless or lacking direction, I believe life’s richer when immersed in diverse cultures and adventures.
My aspiration is to be a committed environmental advocate. Some might see this as idealistic given current global priorities, but addressing climate change is crucial for future generations.

content.text: what are human actions and decisions based on?

outputs.content: Many believe human actions and decisions are guided primarily by emotions. Gut feelings often drive choices more than rationale, leading to unpredictable or seemingly irrational outcomes driven by fear, love, or anger.

From a biological standpoint, humans are often seen as driven by survival instincts. Decisions can be traced back to the primal urge to ensure personal and genetic survival, affecting everything from career choices to interpersonal relationships.

Social norms and cultural upbringing heavily influence decisions. Peer pressure and societal expectations can mold individual choices, resulting in decisions that align more with perceived social acceptance than personal preference.

For some, actions and decisions are rooted in utilitarian ethics, weighing the greatest good for the greatest number. These individuals focus on outcomes and the logical analysis of potential benefits versus harms.

A more cynical view is that human actions are driven by self-interest and power dynamics. Individuals act to maximize personal gain or influence, even when it conflicts with ethical or altruistic considerations.

content.text: What is the best thing someone can do in life

outputs.content: Pursue knowledge relentlessly. Learning opens doors, expands horizons, and fuels personal growth. It can lead to a more fulfilling life as you continue to understand the world and yourself more deeply, constantly improving and adapting.

Achieve financial independence early. Money is often a means to freedom, allowing you to live life on your terms without being constrained by societal expectations or the demands of others. This path, while challenging, offers unparalleled liberty.

Foster meaningful relationships. Human connection is vital for happiness and well-being. Investing in family and friendships can provide support, joy, and a sense of belonging that transcends material achievements or success in career.

Make a positive impact. Whether through charity, activism, or simply spreading kindness daily, focusing on improving the world for others can bring deep satisfaction and purpose, making a lasting difference in countless lives.

Prioritize personal happiness. Focus on what truly makes you happy and fulfilled, whether it's work, hobbies, or self-exploration, without being swayed by external pressures or societal norms. Your happiness can inspire and uplift those around you.

content.text: What makes the world go round?

outputs.content: Innovation and technology are what propel the world forward. As we break barriers in science, our societies grow more interconnected and efficient. Without progress, we would stagnate. Yet, this relentless pursuit sometimes sacrifices the environment and deep human connections.

Love and compassion are the true forces behind the world's motion. From intimate relationships to global humanitarian efforts, they drive individuals and societies to create, inspire, and mend. However, the romanticized ideal often overlooks systemic flaws in human interactions.

Money is the catalyst keeping the world in motion. It's the lifeline for businesses and governments and drives all decision-making processes. While critiqued for creating inequalities, its influence is undeniable and pivotal for tangible developments and innovations.

Competition is the heartbeat of progress, pushing individuals and nations to strive for leadership in various domains. It's this race for superiority that ignites advancements and breakthroughs. The downside is the potential for aggressive tactics and perpetual stress.

Culture and tradition define how societies continue their journey and make the global community vibrant. These elements sustain identities and foster belonging, even if clashing at times with modernity's fast-paced changes and introducing potential conflicts among diverse groups.

content.title: AITA for not allowing my children to eat junk food, watch tv, or play video games?
content.text:
I have two children a 7 year old son and a 9 year old girl. We don’t allow our children to eat junk food, they will sometimes have it if they go to a friends house or on special occasions like Christmas,  but we have zero junk food in our house normally. They sometimes beg me to buy it but normally they’re fine with what they have. We also don’t allow them to watch tv. We do allow them to watch an age appropriate movie at the weekend. And we don’t allow video games because I find absolutely nothing educational about them. Son has started asking to play but we’ve just said no. 

Both our children are happy most the time, they do lots of extracurricular activities, sport/theatre stuff, we teach them how to cook, we play games, we read, they go out on their bikes, play with our dog, listen to music, learn life skills. Both of them are top of their class at school and we are always complimented on how polite and well behaved our children are. 

Sometimes I feel I’m being a little bit harsh on them by restricting them from this stuff, but I also think this stuff is addictive and poisons their minds. Other family members and friends have told us we are way too strict, but Our kids know far more actual life skills than their peers. So AITA for the way I raise my children?

outputs.content: You're doing a great job by prioritizing health and life skills. Children benefit from structure, and your approach fosters discipline and responsibility. Being strict isn't inherently negative if your kids are thriving. Trust your instincts, not outside criticism.

While maintaining boundaries is essential, consider loosening up slightly. Allowing small, controlled exposure to video games or TV could teach balance and self-regulation, potentially alleviating future curiosity. A more flexible approach might enrich their social experiences with friends.

In a world saturated with media, sheltering your kids might inadvertently make them curious or resentful. Allow them choice and autonomy, building critical thinking. Completely eliminating pop culture could isolate them socially, impacting their interpersonal skills.

You've found a formula that works for your family, but being too strict now might lead to rebellion later. Introducing limited screen time could be an opportunity to teach moderation. Balance discipline with understanding, fostering mutual respect and dialogue.

Some degree of strictness can nurture discipline and success. If familial criticism arises from differing parenting styles, remember that each child is unique. If your children are content, your methods align with your values; stay confident in your decisions.

content.title: AITA for wanting break up with GF because she insists on having kids if we ever got married?
content.text:
I've been in a relationship with a woman for 4 years and we've done pretty well so far and have moved in together. However, on the topic of having children it's always contentious.

We've talked about marriage and she always brings up how she wants children. I'm not so excited about it but if I did, I would rather adopt if we did have kids, but to be honest I'd rather have none at all. 

For me, I don't want to give them any of the genes I have that gave me horrible anxiety since I was really young that really interfered with my daily life. Plus, I think the world is regressing with irreversible climate change and as resources and geographies change in the next 40-50 years, I can't say the quality of life would be something I would be looking forward to.

GF will not budge. She wants "her own" kids and to me that's really selfish. I understand why - since it's your biologic compulsion to reproduce - but logic can override impulse and I'd rather have none at all or adopt.

It's driving a serious wedge, but I honestly think I'm in the right.

outputs.content: You should stick to your beliefs; bringing a child into an uncertain world isn't just about fulfilling personal desires. Adopting could provide love and care to a child in need, addressing both personal and global concerns responsibly. Relationships require compromise, but not at any cost.

Perhaps reconsider your stance. While your concerns are valid, they don't necessarily outweigh the potential joy and fulfillment children can bring. Plus, with therapy and resources, you might tackle anxiety without imposing limits on future generations. Relationships are about finding common dreams, not just differences.

If her stance is unwavering, it may signal an insurmountable incompatibility. Love should not force either partner to compromise on non-negotiables like children. It's better to address this truthfully now rather than let it erode the relationship further, potentially leaving both parties resentful.

Focusing exclusively on the negatives might be clouding your perspective. Embrace life's unpredictability; perhaps parenting might offer personal growth and challenge your current anxieties. Collaboratively seeking professional advice could also bridge understanding, helping redefine what "family" might mean to both of you.

Your concern about climate change is valid, but many people argue that having children can drive them to work towards a better future. Perhaps focusing on sustainability within your own family could ease your worries, balancing her desires with your ideals.

content.title: KIDS IN THIRD PLACE WITH GRANDMA
content.text:
our son is 3 years old. our daughter is 5. my parents live an hour away-by car. i recently phoned and asked them to come and stay with their grandchildren for a weekend while we attend a convention in another city.
my mother immediately checked to see if the dates (two months away) were on their "rv group" weekend. since we so rarely ask them to baby-sit, and the children love "nini and papa" so much, i was hurt, and wrote and told them so.
mother wrote back, listing her priorities as follows: (1) her job. (she sells real estate.) (2) her favorite activity. (taking rv group trips with her husband, who is retired.) (3) her grandchildren.
needless to say, i engaged a baby sitter. my parents are now saying that we should understand their need for freedom. abby, they have stayed with our children overnight only once in a year and a half, when we delivered the kids- never have they driven to our home to baby-sit for the evening.
we have decided never again to ask them for anything. are we right or wrong to feel as we do? third place but no show

outputs.content: You might feel hurt, but it's important to respect their desire for independence. Not everyone's priority list aligns perfectly; they still love your children but want personal time. Consider involving them more casually without expectations to foster a stronger relationship.

It's understandable to feel disappointed, but everyone has different priorities. It might help to communicate directly with your parents to convey how much their involvement means to your family. Finding a middle ground could strengthen familial bonds.

He doesn't realize it so he runs at the wall for 5 minutes. He doesn't try to figure it out at all. So he goes to grab his mom. This time I called BS and told him to come back and finish the game. He said he was done and I said no you need to figure this out because I'm tired of watching you quit. He starts to argue and I cut him off. Eventually he finishes the part.
