content.title: 'Only' Child Finally Discovers Half Sisters She Never Knew
content.text:
i am an only child. four years ago, when i was 19, i lost my father to cancer. recently i was sorting through some of dad's papers and found an old will. it said something to the effect that "i, michael, am the father of sarah and anne, both from a previous marriage. when i refer to 'my daughter,' in the remainder of the will, i am speaking only of 'kelly.'" (that's me.) i was floored. i have two older half-sisters i was never told about! growing up, i hated being an only child and begged my parents to have more children.
i do not believe my father was a "deadbeat dad," because he always spoke harshly about individuals who didn't pay child support. he traveled the world in the military and lived in many countries and states before he met my mother.
abby, i am afraid to confront my mother. i know i shouldn't have snooped through my father's old papers, but i feel i had the right to know i have two half-siblings. what do i do now? -- not my father's only precious girl

outputs.content: Consider consulting a therapist to process these emotions first. Once grounded, gently approach your mother with your findings and feelings. It's important to navigate this family revelation with empathy, understanding past choices and their possible complexities.

You owe it to yourself to seek the truth. Confront your mother directly about your discovery. She withheld important information affecting your identity, and you deserve an honest conversation, prepared for possible excuses or further hiding.

Embrace this as an opportunity. Reach out to your half-sisters directly if you can find them. Immediate family might not always hold the answers, and your newfound siblings could offer connection and closure you’ve longed for.

Perhaps consider the potential impact on your relationship with your mother. Sometimes the past is better left alone if it risks damaging precious relationships. Focus on cherishing the bond with your mother and honoring your dad's memory instead.

Channel your feelings into a personal project, such as writing a memoir or journal. This can bring clarity and understanding before any confrontation. It allows exploration of emotions in a private, safe space without immediate repercussions.

content.text: write some questions couples can ask each other to get to know each other more intimately

outputs.content: "What are your core values, and how have they shaped who you are today?" This question encourages introspection and understanding of foundational beliefs, sparking deeper conversations about personal growth and priorities.
"Can you describe a time you felt the proudest of yourself, and why was it significant to you?" This allows partners to share accomplishments and reveal what achievements are most meaningful to them.
"What are your biggest fears, and how do you typically cope with them?" Discussing fears can be vulnerable but builds trust, enabling partners to understand each other’s anxieties and support needs.

"If you could live anywhere in the world, where would it be and why?" This probes future dreams and lifestyle preferences, helping partners align or explore potential differences in future aspirations.

"What kind of childhood did you have, and how do you think it impacts the way you relate to others now?" By reflecting on past experiences, couples can gain insight into behavior patterns shaped in early life.

content.text: Draw an analogy between the human life cycle and the seasons, and explain the connection between each stage and the corresponding season.

outputs.content: Spring represents childhood, where life bursts forth with new beginnings and endless curiosity. Like budding leaves, children grow rapidly and soak up knowledge, preparing for the warmth and energy of summer: adolescence and young adulthood, full of vitality and intensity.

The vigor of youth parallels a long, sunlit summer. As maturity sets in, the autumn years unfold, marked by reflection and harvest – the culmination of life's endeavors. Eventually, we embrace winter's quietude, mirroring elderly years of rest and introspection.

Spring is akin to the innocent wonder of childhood, filled with learning as seeds do in soil. Summer's heat echoes the tumultuous emotional experiences of adolescence. Autumn's tranquility represents maturity, while winter mirrors the wisdom and serene acceptance of old age.

Each season symbolizes a stage of life: the energetic growth of spring is our childhood, the productive, peak of summer is young adulthood, the reflective transformation of autumn signals middle age, and winter’s dormancy arrives with the calm solitude of old age.

Spring captures childhood’s eagerness, leading to summer’s embodiment of reckless youth and discoveries. The autumn of middle age brings change, shedding old habits for wiser paths, while winter’s cold serenity wraps around the wisdom and rest of our final phase.

content.text: lets say i have build a underground bunker of 40 level, what should the 40 levels be used for?

outputs.content: Each level could serve a different purpose. For example, levels could include storage, living quarters, agriculture, recreation, a command center, and a research lab. Ideally, the levels enhance long-term survival, maintaining both physical and mental well-being of inhabitants.

Why bother with variety? Use the whole bunker for a single purpose like a global art preservation archive. That ensures the world's greatest cultural artifacts are secured in one consolidated, virtually indestructible location, protected from any surface calamities.

Transform it into a luxury underground hotel with each level dedicated to different world themes or experiences. This could attract thrill-seekers and wealthy patrons who wish to indulge in an exclusive and unique subterranean adventure.

It's overkill! Instead, focus on making a confined space livable. Have storage only because any more is wasteful paranoia. Survivalists obsess too much over a dystopian future instead of improving the present world we live in.

Develop a self-sustaining ecosystem with agriculture, livestock, renewable energy, and water purification systems. This approach emphasizes sustainability and independence, making the facility an excellent educational and research hub for future urban planning and survival techniques.

content.text: what is the first thing a dolphin will tell us if it can speak?

outputs.content: "Your oceans are in trouble, and we need help to keep them clean and safe for all marine life." This highlights an advocacy perspective, focusing on environmental concerns and the impact of human activity on the oceans.

"We have intricate social structures and emotions you might find surprising—our pod dynamics are as complex as any human family." This viewpoint emphasizes the dolphin's intelligence and social complexity, advocating for better understanding and mutual respect.

"We don't really enjoy your aquariums and entertainment shows; they are prisons. We value freedom and space, much like humans." This response comes from an animal rights perspective, arguing against captivity and promoting animal welfare.

"You might not realize it, but surfing the waves is our favorite gig, and sometimes we do it just to show off for you." A playful, light-hearted response, focusing on dolphins' natural behaviors and curiosity in their interactions with humans.

"We have our songs, not unlike your music, and maybe one day we can jam together—oceans can be our concert halls." This highlights a cultural exchange perspective, recognizing the beauty in shared experiences across different species.

content.title: AITA for telling people to stop complaining when they do favors for me?
content.text:
Okay, this totally sounds like I'm being a dick, but let me explain. A lot of the time I'll ask my friends for favors. Pour me a glass of water since you're in the kitchen, drive me to school, etc. I'll ask, and then sometimes they'll go, "UGGGGHHHH, fine. Can't you do it yourself?"

"You don't have to do it," I say. "You can say no. I won't be mad."

"UGH, no, it's fine. I'll fucking do it."

"Are you sure? You really sound like you don't want to. I can just do it if you're not up for it."

"No, I'll just do the stupid favor!"

"Alright, well either don't do it, or stop whining about it!"

I feel like an asshole because I'm so harsh at a person who's willing to do something for me, but at the same time, they clearly don't want to do it, so why do it and complain when I repeatedly tell them that they don't have to?

outputs.content: Maybe your friends feel a sense of obligation, fearing rejection or guilt if they refuse. Consider offering something in return or reducing their load to encourage an easier 'no' when they're uncomfortable helping.
Some people genuinely find it difficult to say no, even when they truly want to. Try to be more self-reliant and request favors only when absolutely necessary to avoid putting them in that position.

Perhaps your friends' reactions are a sign of deeper resentment over always assisting you. Reflect on whether you're overly dependent on them and strive to balance the give-and-take in your relationships.

If you're clear about them having a choice, then it's on them to set boundaries. However, lowering the frequency of requests could alleviate their aggravation and promote a healthier friendship dynamic.

It's possible your friends feel like you're taking advantage of their kindness even if unintentional. Engage in an open conversation to address the underlying frustration and recalibrate the relationship towards mutual respect.

content.title: AITA (or we, wife and I) for buying a house in an underserved Hispanic community?
content.text:
Will keep this very short but can add INFO if needed. Wife and I came into some nice inheritance in mid 2018. We decided that we are going to use the money to see the world and live in exotic places while trying to get our dream careers going (me: writer, she: clothing designer). We also wanted to live in underserved communities where we could be around real people instead of the Dallas suburbs we grew up in or in gentrified SoHo where we moved from.


We decided on South Tucson, AZ. It is 90% Hispanic, historic and gorgeous. We were able to buy a house for a song and we eagerly moved in 2 weeks ago. However the reception has not been good. At first we figured that maybe we were the first open lesbian couple they had seen so we went around and introduced ourself last week and people were either not friendly and our 65 year old neighbor told us that white people like us only bring problems to the neighborhood. We asked her to explain, she said if she has to explain then we truly don’t get it. 

I don’t think we are assholes but I sure felt like it  after speaking with our neighbor. We are just trying to experience a different culture...I thought that was a good thing.

outputs.content: You might consider reaching out with genuine curiosity and a willingness to listen. Attend local events, support community initiatives, and volunteer. Proving you're there to integrate—not change—the neighborhood could help bridge cultural gaps and foster acceptance.

If the reception remains unwelcoming, it may be worth reflecting on the potential for unintended gentrification. Reevaluating your intentions or considering relocating to a community that's more receptive to your presence could provide a more harmonious environment.

This experience could serve as writing inspiration. Document your interactions and the journey of understanding cultural tensions. Such firsthand insights could enhance your storytelling and your wife's designs, enriching your work with authentic experiences.

Decision fatigue might be weighing you two down more than anticipated. Seeking out a diverse community was noble, but there's no shame in admitting maybe this wasn't the right fit. Perhaps seek professional guidance to mediate better cultural understanding.

Push harder into integrating with the community. Host events to showcase your talents—community readings or fashion shows. Maybe the introduction of your skills will lower barriers and encourage your neighbors to engage with you on a different level.

content.title: SUCH CHARITY IS MISDIRECTED
content.text:
i am to be married soon and have a very serious problem to face. my fiance's father is seriously ill. (he's terminal.) the doctors have just given him a period of time to live, which comes very close to our wedding date. we set our wedding date four months ago--before we knew how sick he was.
if he is called by god close to our wedding date, what is the proper etiquette with regard to our wedding? how can we handle the joy of our wedding with the sorrow of his passing, which will be mourned by my fiance's mother and the rest of his family?
please answer soon as there isn't much time. happy and sad

outputs.content: Consider postponing the wedding. With your fiancé's family grieving, a ceremony can feel inappropriate during their mourning period. Discuss with family members to gauge their emotions and come to a consensus that honors both celebration and loss.

Proceed with the wedding as planned, while incorporating a tribute to your fiancé's father. This could be a moment of silence or a small dedication, acknowledging the complexity of joy and grief intertwined.
Focus on a smaller, intimate ceremony even if the date is unchanged. This respects the mourning yet allows you to honor your commitment to one another, providing some solace amidst the sorrow.

Cancel the wedding for now out of respect for your fiancé's family. It may feel daunting, but prioritizing their emotional needs shows consideration for their grief, leaving the celebration for a more appropriate time.

Leave the decision to your fiancé's family, offering to adapt your plans based on what they feel comfortable with. This shows you prioritize their emotional well-being and are willing to share this transition phase with them respectfully.

content.title: MOM UPSET BY NEW PART-TIME ROLE
content.text:
during the past 10 years, i have raised four children. the last two are twins. as the school year begins, i see my babies going off to school full time. what happens now?
we can't wait until our children say their first words, take their first steps, are finally out of diapers, and then-boom, they are off to kindergarten!
i actually looked forward to their being in school all day, but now that it has happened, i am lost. i don't know what to do with myself. i ask myself if i should take up a hobby or get a job. or perhaps have another baby?
am i crazy for feeling this way? are there others out there who have felt this way? brentwood, n.y., mom

outputs.content: You're definitely not alone. Many parents experience a sense of loss when their children start school. It might be worth exploring hobbies or volunteering in the community. Finding a new purpose or routine can help fill the gap!

Maybe this is the perfect time to focus on self-care and rediscover your identity outside motherhood. Consider taking classes or pursuing interests you put on hold. You've dedicated so much time to your kids; now it's about you!

Jumping back into the workforce could bring a sense of accomplishment and purpose. It's not uncommon to feel a bit disoriented now, but finding a job might provide a structured and fulfilling daily routine.

Thinking about having another baby is natural if you feel lost without the hustle of early parenting. However, ensure it's what both you and your partner want and not just a reaction to feeling unsure or isolated.

It's okay to feel conflicted; motherhood is a big part of your identity. Seeking a community of other parents might provide support and ideas on how to navigate this phase. Sharing experiences can be incredibly validating.

content.text: Got any creative ideas for a 8 year old’s birthday?

outputs.content: How about a scavenger hunt around the neighborhood to find hidden treasures? It combines outdoor adventure with problem-solving and teamwork, offering kids an exciting experience and a sense of achievement.

Host a science-themed party where kids rotate between different DIY experiment stations. They can make slime, launch mini rockets, or create simple circuits, fostering creativity and an interest in science from an early age.

Organize a costume fashion show where kids can dress as their favorite characters or fictional heroes. Provide a runway and encourage creativity with DIY costumes and decorations, ensuring everyone gets a turn in the spotlight.

Rent a mobile petting zoo and have an animal-themed day. Kids can interact with and learn about different animals, providing a hands-on educational experience that combines fun with a bit of wildlife awareness.

Set up a digital escape room at home, where kids solve puzzles and clues to "escape" from a themed scenario. Use printable materials or an app and tailor it to be age-appropriate, ensuring everyone is engaged and entertained.

content.text: What is the meaning of life

outputs.content: Life's meaning is subjective, defined by individual goals and desires. For some, it's about finding happiness through love and relationships. Others see purpose in personal success or spiritual growth. It's a personal journey to discover what brings fulfillment.

The meaning of life is a human construct; there's no inherent purpose. We exist by chance in an indifferent universe. Accept this and create your own meaning through experiences, creativity, and impact on others, embracing life's fleeting beauty without cosmic significance.

Life's meaning is rooted in service to others and the greater good. By helping those in need and contributing to society, we find purpose and fulfillment. This altruistic approach builds community and leaves a positive legacy, giving life profound significance.

For some, the meaning of life is found in religious or spiritual beliefs. It's fulfilling the purpose set by a higher power, where life on Earth is a preparation for an eternal existence, guided by faith and adherence to moral principles.

Life holds no universal meaning; it's a pursuit of hedonism and personal satisfaction. We should prioritize enjoyment, seizing every moment to indulge in pleasures and desires without guilt, ensuring our time is filled with joy and excitement before it ends.

content.text: Tell me what to prioritise in life

outputs.content: Focus on personal happiness and fulfillment. Life is too short to be lived for others; find what truly makes you happy and prioritize it, even if it means unconventional choices or against societal norms.
I believe family should be the top priority. They're the people who will stick by you through thick and thin, and nurturing those relationships is crucial for a fulfilling life.

Career advancement should come first. In the long run, your professional success will secure financial stability and personal satisfaction, providing a sense of achievement that spills over into other areas of life.

Prioritize your health above everything else. Without physical and mental well-being, you cannot fully enjoy your accomplishments or relationships. Make time for exercise, healthy eating, and mental health resources.
Live to serve others; prioritize community and altruism. By helping those in need, you create a meaningful impact, leaving a legacy and often finding personal happiness through selfless acts.

content.title: AITA for letting my boyfriend's passport expire before our trip?
content.text:
My boyfriend of over a year and I are going to an out of country destination for a week in March. I love him a lot but he can be juvenile and I find myself feeling at times likes a mother and child dynamic.

His passport has been expired since May 2018, and I have brought it up several times to get it renewed. We have even had a tiff or two over it. In November, we booked and paid for this trip. It cost about 1000$ each. 

The deadline of him needing to have his passport sent off so he can get it back in time is approaching quickly. I guess I'm asking preemptively to this so I know if I'd be an asshole if I followed through with what I am currently intending on doing : I'm not going to say shit and let him deal with the consequences if he doesn't get it together on time. I'll have a lovely vacation on my own. 

Be honest. Would that make me an asshole to knowingly let him miss out on our trip?

outputs.content: You're not an asshole. Adults should be responsible for their own documents, especially since you’ve reminded him several times. Enjoying your vacation alone might be exactly what he needs to learn from his oversight and mature a bit.

It might seem harsh, but letting him miss out may emphasize personal accountability. You'll come across as cold, but it could be a tough-love lesson he needs. Just be prepared for possible fallout in the relationship from this approach.

Consider another reminder, as a final effort to show your care. His lapse doesn't mean he should miss a shared experience. You'd feel less guilty and, if he still misses out, it's clearly on him without that burden hanging over you.

This approach might be unfair. If the relationship matters to you, help him. It could benefit your partnership's growth, saving him from disappointment and maturing even a juvenile side. Such support might alleviate your 'mothering' role over time.

Actively participating in his mistake allows for mutual understanding and stronger communication. Outline the deadline and consequence clearly once more. If he still fails, it'll reinforce the importance of preparedness without damaging the relationship by seeming indifferent.

content.title: AITA for telling my mum she wasn’t a great parent when she criticised gay people having kids...
content.text:
Ok so we were having a discussion the other day about gay people having children. My mum said kids should have a mother and father 🙄. I said there’s plenty of people who split up, a parent dies etc and the kid is fine. She said but having a mother and father is still better...I said not necessarily. If those parents were abusive, poor and couldn’t care properly for their kids then they’re not gonna be better than two parents of the same sex who aren’t abusive and can financially and emotionally support their kids. She then said that money had nothing to do with it and a poor heterosexual would be much better parents than a financially stable gay couple 🤦🏻‍♀️ 

I said that’s bullshit. I said us not having a lot of money growing up did badly affect me. It made everything a lot harder, my mental and physical health suffered because of it. I also said that my parents constant arguing and fighting with one another, plus my mothers constant screaming at me affected me badly and it would have been better for me to be bought up by gay people who could finically support me and who didn’t give me severe anxiety from the constant fighting. 

She’s now not talking to me. Calling me disrespectful, saying she gave up a lot for me and I’m ungrateful. 

So AITA for saying this, or is she the asshole?

outputs.content: You're justified in emphasizing a stable, loving environment over sexual orientation or socio-economic status. It's about highlighting quality parenting. However, the way you addressed it may have been harsh, unintentionally damaging your mother's feelings. Perspective matters, especially with family.

Perhaps you should have taken a more empathetic approach. Respectfully disagreeing allows for healthier dialogue, especially with sensitive topics. Persuasion often works better with understanding, and acknowledging her sacrifices might help bridge the gap in conversations like this one.

Your mom's view can be seen as outdated but common among older generations. While your points are valid, outright dismissing her views without understanding her context can seem disrespectful. Sometimes, agreeing to disagree maintains family harmony without compromising beliefs.

Discussing differences in upbringing can quickly turn emotional. Instead of framing the argument as "who's right," consider focusing on understanding why she feels strongly. Maybe her perspective comes from personal experiences, potentially providing a backdrop for common ground and future dialogue.

It's unfortunate conversations like this often need a 'correct' side. Cultures evolve, and opening this dialogue suggests growth. Yet, it highlights she isn't versed in such changes, which doesn't necessarily make her wrong, just hesitant to shift her long-held beliefs.

content.title: Eager Little Leaguers Suffer Major League Disappointment
content.text:
my husband, "greg," and i dated five years before we married two years ago. greg is catholic and i am southern baptist. his family was aware of our religious differences from the beginning. we were completely candid that neither of us would convert from our religions, and that our children would be raised baptist until they were old enough to decide otherwise.
on our wedding day, no one from greg's family showed up, and i watched tears stream down my husband's face on what should have been the happiest day of his life. it has been very difficult ever since. his parents christened our child at their home without greg's or my consent. there have been other problems -- too numerous to mention.
the last straw came three months ago. greg's older sibling was also married in a non-catholic church. this time, the entire family, including us, attended.
the problem with greg's parents has caused a major strain on our marriage. we have invited them over on numerous occasions to hash out our differences, but they have never showed up. after our last attempt, they said they had nothing else to talk to us about.
abby, i feel no love lost because of their absence, and my toddler really doesn't know them anyway. however, i am concerned about my husband's feelings. he and my child mean the world to me. i don't want my marriage to suffer. i'm worried that if this continues much longer, i'll lose my temper with the situation. can you help us? -- losing my cool in georgia

outputs.content: Perhaps consider seeing a family counselor who specializes in interfaith relationships. Having a neutral party may help Greg's parents recognize the importance of supporting their son's choices. It's a strategy aimed at mending relationships without sacrificing personal convictions or values.

Focus on building your own family's happiness and traditions that celebrate both your faiths. If Greg's parents continue being distant, limit their influence on your marriage. Encourage Greg to express his feelings, while prioritizing mutual respect within your unit, fostering intimacy and understanding.

Reconsider inviting them into your lives. Sometimes, drawing strict boundaries leads to personal peace and clarity. Let Greg's parents decide when they're ready to engage meaningfully. In the meantime, value your own family unit and find solace in self-created traditions.

Empathy towards Greg is crucial. Encourage him to articulate his feelings and consider therapy to heal the wounds inflicted by family, providing him with emotional tools to cope. It may not mend the familial rift, but it can strengthen your marriage’s foundation.

You might try writing a heartfelt letter explaining the impact this has had on Greg. Sometimes, seeing emotions in writing can evoke understanding. If they remain unmoved, consider accepting this rift, focusing on teaching your child the values you both cherish.

content.title: Son Learns Mom Is Stepping Out on Dad While He's in Jail
content.text:
my father went to prison five years ago, and my mother has been taking care of my brother and sister. (i'm older and out of the house.)
i recently came across some shocking information. mom has been going on dates with a clergy member who has been sending her text messages saying things like "i can't stop thinking about you," etc. i also found out she has a profile on a couple of internet dating sites and has been coming home later than usual after going out "for drinks with friends" after work. when i confronted her, she first denied it, then got caught in a lie. she refuses to accept responsibility, insisting "it wasn't a date," although this man expressed romantic feelings for her.
my father knows nothing about this while he languishes in a cell for what could be another five or six years. should i tell him? i also do not know if i should confront this clergyman because i find his actions despicable.
how can i explain to my mother that what she's doing is wrong? when i try to talk to her in a mature way, she says things like, "i can't hear you!" any advice you can offer would be appreciated. -- disillusioned son in new jersey

outputs.content: Consider the emotional strain your mother is under. Her actions may stem from loneliness or unmet needs. Approach her without judgment, acknowledging her feelings and asking how you can support her, rather than confronting her as "disillusioned."

You have a right to feel disillusioned, but your mom deserves compassion too. Suggest family therapy to improve communication among all children and her. This can address underlying issues without anyone feeling attacked or judged.

Focus on supporting your father. Informing him might cause more pain without changing the situation. Maintain your relationship with both parents, while accepting your mother's choices, even if you don't agree with them.

Take a stand by contacting the clergyman and expressing your discomfort. Push for accountability, emphasizing that clergy should uphold moral standards. This may also signal your mother that her actions don’t go unnoticed and have consequences.

It might be tempting to tell your dad or confront the clergyman, but it could backfire. Instead, focus on your siblings' well-being. Offer stability and support, ensuring they're coping with the family dynamics effectively.

content.text: I'm going to Vienna with my gf and my mother for 3 days in august. Make me a plan

outputs.content: Focus on historical sites, starting with Schönbrunn Palace and then a day in the art museums: start with the Kunsthistorisches Museum and later, the Belvedere. Dine at local eateries to experience authentic Viennese cuisine, and enjoy a concert at the Musikverein one evening.

Prioritize relaxation and local experiences. Spend a day at the Prater enjoying rides, stroll through Naschmarkt for food and shopping, and take a leisurely Danube River cruise. Opt for quaint cafes and an open-air dinner at the Danube Tower's revolving restaurant.

Plan a mix of guided tours and free exploration. Book a guided walking tour for key historical insights, then leave room for spontaneous visits to hidden cafes or alleys. Consider a quick day trip to nearby towns like Baden or Krems.

Immerse fully in Vienna’s cultural events. Attend the Vienna Festival for unique performances and workshops. Devote another day to revisiting childhood with visits to interactive museums, and enjoy a wine-tasting tour amidst the Vienna Woods for a serene conclusion.

Go minimalist and relax. Spend time at coffeehouses like Café Central, savoring local pastries. Visit only a couple of major attractions to avoid burnout. Engage with locals at small artisan shops for a more authentic experience, avoiding mainstream tourist spots.

content.title: AITA for wanting to sleep at night while my wife takes care of our newborn?
content.text:
My wife and I just had our second kid last week and I want to sleep at night while she takes care of the nightly feedings and diaper changing.

My wife is on maternity leave and she had no complications with the birth and is not bed ridden or anything. Our oldest daughter gets dropped off at daycare and my wife takes care of the newborn during the day and does household chores and such.

I went back to work on Monday working an office job 9-6 and it’s not a stressful job or anything. I also stay up till about 12-1 doing homework for my MBA. I do help with the newborn when I am home and for anything my wife or baby needs till I go to sleep. 

I want to be able to sleep through the night since I’m up late and have to work in the morning but my wife expects me to wake up every 2-3 hours and help with feedings and stuff while she pumps to try to get met milk in. 

AMTA for not wanting to wake up and help?

outputs.content: You might consider balancing night duties more evenly. Although your job requires focus and you're pursuing an MBA, it's essential for your partner to get rest too—you're both parents after all. Perhaps splitting nights or taking turns could be a fair compromise.

Given you work an office job and aren't sleep-deprived at work, it's fair to support your wife at night. Shared responsibilities, especially in the early weeks, can foster a stronger partnership. Consider adjusting your routine to prioritize these critical first months with your newborn.

If you already stay up till midnight, it could be reasonable to take on a feeding during that time. While your wife does more overnight, this still shows you're engaged and supportive. Ensuring she has consecutive sleep hours could make a huge difference.

You could focus on weekend nights to give your wife some relief since you don’t need to wake up as early. During the workweek, perhaps you could take on more of the evening responsibilities to balance the load without sacrificing your sleep.

It's understandable to prioritize sleep for work and studies, but nighttime support is crucial too. Perhaps align weekend and weekday responsibilities differently, allowing both of you adequate rest at times, and reinforce shared parenting goals which can strengthen your bond.

content.title: AITA for telling my wife I was away for a business trip, when really I went on a city break on my own?
content.text:
I love my wife but she is awful to travel with. She's a bit of a princess and she doesn't care about art or architecture. She wears stupid shoes and walks too slow, but gets tired of places too fast.

I did originally have a meeting in London but it got cancelled and I still wanted to go, so I booked myself into a fancy hotel, went to galleries, rode the subway and ate in amazing restaurants for three nights. Aw man it was awesome. I just enjoyed not caring about her being entertained and being alone to my thoughts.

I just kept thinking the whole time I was there how she wouldn't have liked it, and would have ruined it. If I'd have told her about it she would have come with me, no question. 

Am I an asshole?

outputs.content: Not at all. Everyone needs some personal space and time to enjoy the things they love. You respecting her disinterest by going alone and leaving her out seems considerate, not selfish. Enjoying your individuality strengthens your relationship.

Yes, hiding it and using negative assumptions about her reactions could be seen as inconsiderate. Your partnership should involve communication and compromise, not secret escapes. Consider discussing and finding mutual ground or activities to share when traveling together.

You're not necessarily an asshole, but perhaps lacking empathy. Her presence might alter your experience, but it's worth finding activities that could bring you both joy. Balance your needs with hers, fostering joint happiness rather than separation.

You might be, if you're not open about your desires for solo trips. Everyone has quirks, and navigating them together is part of partnership. However, true independence can be healthy and needed. Just be transparent about your intent.

Absolutely not. Relationships thrive on individuals being fulfilled independently at times. You deserve to experience cultural joys freely without feeling guilty. It’s not about sneaking away, but doing something for yourself, a crucial aspect of self-care. Keep communication open.

content.title: ALCOHOLIC'S PLIGHT UPSETS STRANGER
content.text:
i placed an ad in our local lincoln paper to "drive your car to any destination for a fee." this morning a lady called, wanting me to drive her to a retirement home in texas. after the price was agreed upon, i went to her apartment in lincoln.
when she met me at the door she was crying, saying she was an alcoholic --and a very sick woman--and could i please help her. the poor woman was shaking, so i suggested we call a family member as i had never seen this lady before in my life. (there is alcoholism in my family, so my heart went out to her.) she said she was 69, but she looked much older. she started shaking badly, and began looking for her bottle. (she had bottles hidden all over the place, but the ones i found were empty!) we visited for half an hour, then she fell asleep on the couch, so i called the apartment manager who turned out to be a young lady about 35. she said, "leave her alone; don't get involved. go on home."
i went home, but, abby, this poor lady has called me five times asking me to come back. part of me says, "go back and try to help her," and the other half says, "listen to the manager--don't get involved."
i feel guilty because like most people, i don't want to get involved, but i can't get this lady out of my mind. she said she has no family. what would you do in a case like this? w.f., palmyra, neb.

outputs.content: I would respect the apartment manager's advice. As someone without the expertise in dealing with addiction, getting involved might cause more harm than good. Reporting her situation to a local social service may be a more responsible step to ensure her well-being.

I would go back and offer her a ride to a local Alcoholics Anonymous meeting or a nearby rehabilitation center. Sometimes what people need is a little push and company during their first step towards recovery. It could make a difference in her life.

I believe in personal responsibility. She has already made her choice to live like this, and it isn't my problem. There's only so much you can do—everyone is ultimately responsible for their own actions and decisions, no matter how sad.

Perhaps compromise is the best approach. I would call a helpline or find a local support group and pass on their contact information to her. This way, I provide a resource without directly involving myself in a potentially draining situation.

I'd probably listen to my gut instinct and help her despite the manager's advice. Sometimes the risk of getting involved is worth it if it means potentially helping someone in need, especially when they have no one else to turn to.

content.title: Cold Hearted Comment Turns Bedroom Into Deep Freeze
content.text:
my 12-year-old niece, "amanda," is on her cell phone constantly. she is the smartest kid i know, but she is failing her classes and has started to lie about everything. i raised her until she was 5 -- i was only 12 myself when i started -- so i am very close to her. or so i thought.
amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington

outputs.content: Consider scheduling a dedicated time each week to engage in activities Amanda enjoys, without mentioning school or phones. Building trust away from stressors could help her feel more comfortable opening up to you about her struggles.

I suggest a frank conversation with her parents. They need to be on the same page to address her behavior consistently as a team. You can offer support but ultimately it's their responsibility to set boundaries and enforce them.

Perhaps it's time to prioritize her relationship with a counselor. She might be dealing with underlying issues that she feels uncomfortable discussing with family. Professional help can offer insights and solutions beyond what family conversations can achieve.

Show her empathy and understanding rather than disappointment. Pressuring her might push her away further. Let her know you’re there unconditionally, even if she’s making mistakes. Sometimes knowing someone is in your corner can alleviate stress and encourage openness.

Maybe it's about curbing her phone usage altogether. Talk to her parents about implementing strict phone time limits or using parental controls. It might be drastic, but sometimes restrictions lead to better habits and improvements in academic performance.

content.text: embarrassment and shame keep me from being honest with my girlfriend. List some ways to work on this.

outputs.content: Consider seeking individual therapy to explore the roots of your embarrassment. Understanding why you feel shame can make it easier to communicate openly with your girlfriend and ultimately strengthen your relationship.

Try journaling your thoughts before conversations. Writing down what you want to express can relieve tension and embarrassment, helping to organize your feelings and approach your girlfriend with more clarity and confidence.

You might prioritize building trust gradually. Start by sharing minor embarrassments to establish a pattern of honesty, which can make it less intimidating to share more significant issues as your comfort grows.

Reflect on why honesty is important in your relationship and how dishonesty could lead to greater issues. Sometimes rationalizing the need for transparency can motivate a more open dialogue despite feelings of shame.

Some believe that full vulnerability leads to emotional freedom. Consider diving into complete honesty with your girlfriend, displaying your true self as a means of testing and ultimately strengthening your relationship's foundation.

content.text: if life was a videogame, what would the core stats and attributes be?

outputs.content: If life were a video game, core stats would be intelligence, charisma, and strength for navigating challenges. Luck would be a controversial wildcard, allowing random success that frustrates others who rely on hard-earned skills and perseverance.

Endurance, creativity, and adaptability would be the most essential attributes. In life's game, the ability to persevere, innovate solutions, and adjust to unforeseen circumstances is crucial for long-term success, regardless of initial resources.

The primary stats would be empathy, integrity, and ambition. Empathy fosters cooperation; integrity maintains personal and communal morale; ambition drives goals. However, this trio might not appeal to those who prioritize personal gain over collective well-being.

content.title: AITA for being hurt by my daughter's name change
content.text:
My wife kept her last name when we married, but we gave my last name to our children. My daughter changed her name to her husband's when she got married. They are now in the process of a divorce.

My daughter mentioned today that she wants to change her last name not back to my name, but to her mother's name. She wants to honor everything my wife has done for her.

I'm a little hurt by this and told her so. She's free to do as she pleases, but the presentation of it all just makes it feel like she values her mother's contribution over mine. AITA?

outputs.content: It's natural to feel hurt, but consider the deeper meaning behind her choice. By taking her mother's name, she isn't rejecting yours; she's expressing gratitude towards her mom. Appreciate her decision as a unique way of honoring family.

You're entitled to your feelings, and expressing them is valid. However, question why this decision touches such a nerve. Is it truly about the name, or more about perceived equality in parental contributions? Reflect before feeling resentment.

Your daughter sees her name change as an homage to her mom, not a slight against you. It might be beneficial to support her autonomy, showing that your love isn't bound to a name but to her well-being.

It's understandable to be upset, but remember, familial relationships aren't defined by someone's last name. Her decision could be influenced by her divorce, seeking something fresh and autonomous. Focus on your bond with her, not her surname choice.

Feeling hurt is okay, but consider viewing her decision from a different angle. It’s perhaps an opportunity to embrace and celebrate your wife's legacy too. Your daughter's choice doesn't erase or diminish your role in her life.

content.title: AITA for warning this guy about his date
content.text:
I'm a waiter at a sports bar. There's this girl who comes in with a different guy almost every week. Very rarely does she bring the same guy twice, and she's always pulling the same moves with these guys.

She went to the bathroom and I just went over to her date and let him know that his date was here all the time with different guys and he should be careful. He left pretty quickly after that. The girl apparently complained about it, because my boss wrote me up.

AITA for trying to be a bro?

outputs.content: Yes, you are. It's not your responsibility to meddle in her personal life. Your job is to provide excellent service, not to judge customers' choices. You possibly broke trust with your boss and risked your job over something that wasn't your business.

No, you were just looking out for him. Sometimes people appreciate a heads-up, especially if someone might not have the best intentions. It might not be your job, but it's understandable wanting to give a fellow guy some insider information.

Honestly, everyone is entitled to privacy, and you crossed a line. People often have complex lives, so imposing your judgments could have consequences. You should have stayed focused on delivering good service and left personal matters out of it.

While your intentions might have been good, it wasn't your place. What she does is her business, and unless you're asked directly for input, it's better to stay neutral. The boss's write-up was probably fair as it affected customer satisfaction.

Your actions were inappropriate. Whether or not you aimed to help, you disrupted the customer's experience. You have to put personal opinions aside in your work environment; protecting the bar's reputation and ensuring all customers feel comfortable should be priority.

content.title: HALF-TRUTHS TELL THE WHOLE STORY
content.text:
i need your advice about something-sales clerks. i can't stand them! they aggravate me beyond belief. sometimes i even leave the store if they really get to me. i try not to ask for their help because when i do, they stick to me like glue until i leave the store. if i go to try something on, they will be waiting for me to tell me how good i look.
abby, when i try something on, i like to look at it alone and think about buying it, not feel like i'm pressured for time to get out of the change room. if sales clerks want to sell something, they have to give the customer space and privacy.
in the meantime, do you know of a way to tell these salespeople that their help is appreciated, but you would like to be left alone? sign me ... too much attention

outputs.content: "Hi there, I really appreciate your assistance and can tell you’re good at what you do, but I need some alone time to decide. If I need anything, I’ll be sure to ask for you specifically. Thanks!"
You could try shopping online if in-person clerks trigger you. You’ll have zero interaction with salespeople and plenty of time to deliberate your purchases in the comfort of your own home.

Consider reflecting on this. Maybe try viewing their eagerness as a positive attempt to ensure you have a good experience. They’re just doing their job. Who knows, their input may actually be valuable!
Maybe you could bring a friend along who can be your intermediary. They can engage the clerk while keeping the pressure off you, allowing you to focus on your shopping without interruption.

You could directly say, "Thanks, I appreciate the help, but I'd like to browse independently for now," and maintain distance. Often, clear communication helps set the desired boundaries without offending anyone.

content.title: Woman Wonders if It Is Ok to Settle for Mr. Almost Right
content.text:
some new neighbors moved into our beautiful neighborhood recently. this couple, who seem very nice, have gotten an adorable puppy i'll call "taffy."
taffy is now about 6 months old. they leave her in front of their house, completely alone, for most of the day and all night. from what we can see, that poor dog is never allowed inside. taffy craves affection, and we all stop to pet her whenever we go by the house, just to allay some of her loneliness and boredom.
how should we deal with this painful situation? do we dare say anything to the owners -- which will obviously cause "neighbor difficulties"? please advise. -- sally in san diego

outputs.content: Consider organizing a neighborhood meeting to discuss pet care practices and express concerns collectively. This way, it feels less confrontational and more like a community effort to improve Taffy's life, minimizing one-on-one tension with the owners.

Directly speak to the neighbors with kindness and express your concerns for Taffy. Sometimes, people don't realize the impact of their actions until someone points it out. A sincere conversation might encourage them to change their behavior.

Involve animal welfare organizations anonymously. They can assess whether Taffy’s conditions meet animal care standards without implicating you directly, preserving neighborly relations while ensuring Taffy gets the help she needs.

Respect their decisions and status as pet owners. Perhaps they have reasons we don't understand. Simply continue offering Taffy affection when you see her; after all, it's possible she is being well cared for beyond what meets the eye.

Create a neighborhood dog-walking rota. Offer to take Taffy out for some exercise and company during the day. This approach avoids confrontation, provides Taffy with companionship, and allows you to keep a positive relationship with the owners.

content.text: What are values that are important to people?

outputs.content: Many people consider honesty crucial. Living truthfully and being reliable can build trust and foster relationships, which some see as the foundation of both personal and professional success.
For some, freedom stands above all. The ability to express oneself, make choices without coercion, and pursue personal goals is seen as vital for a fulfilling life and genuine happiness.
A significant number of individuals prioritize loyalty. Having unwavering support from those around them provides a sense of security and belonging, often deemed essential for emotional well-being.
Others might advocate for innovation as a key value. Pushing boundaries, embracing new ideas, and fostering creativity allows for progress and adaptation in an ever-changing world.

Community-oriented people may value altruism. The belief that selflessly helping others enhances collective well-being and creates a more compassionate society appeals to those focused on empathy and social justice.

Maximize digital solutions by setting up an immersive light projection that turns your living room into a winter wonderland. Embrace technology to create a unique, futuristic holiday vibe, appealing to tech enthusiasts and modern holiday decorators.

Go all-out on DIY decorations: craft paper snowflakes, homemade garlands, and personalized ornaments. Involve the family in crafting sessions to fill the house with creative, personal touches that resist consumerism and favor sentimental value.

Overhaul your playlist with unconventional holiday tunes, like indie covers or alternative festive music, to avoid clichéd songs and add a fresh, edgy energy. It'll appeal to those tired of traditional carols yet eager for holiday cheer.

Focus solely on scents: bake holiday cookies and use cinnamon or pine-scented candles. Prioritize the olfactory experience, creating a cozy atmosphere through smells alone, which might surprise and delight those who underestimate the power of aroma.

content.text: what's the most important world historical event?

outputs.content: The Industrial Revolution transformed economies and societies, leading to advancements in technology and production. While it advanced human progress, it also paved the way for environmental challenges and disparities in wealth distribution that remain prevalent today.

The fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 marked the end of the Cold War and symbolized the triumph of democracy over communism. For many, it represents a turning point towards global peace and increased political freedom.

The discovery of antibiotics in the early 20th century revolutionized medical science. It drastically reduced mortality rates from infections and improved quality of life, although it also led to challenges like antibiotic resistance.

The events of September 11, 2001, reshaped global security and foreign policy, affecting international relations and public perceptions of safety. It brought about a new era of anti-terrorism measures, influencing global politics significantly.

Some argue the signing of the Magna Carta in 1215 laid the foundation for modern democracy. Its principles of limiting power and ensuring rights have reverberated through history, although its immediate impact was limited.
